news_summary: Global efforts advance human rights through progress on international justice, increased political engagement in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, strengthened EU security cooperation, and growing female political participation in the Ivory Coast.
news_summary_fr: Les efforts déployés au niveau mondial font progresser les droits de l'homme grâce à des avancées en matière de justice internationale, à un engagement politique accru en République démocratique du Congo, au renforcement de la coopération de l'UE en matière de sécurité et à l'augmentation de la participation politique des femmes en Côte d'Ivoire.
news_summary_es: La labor mundial en favor de los derechos humanos se traduce en avances en la justicia internacional, un mayor compromiso político en la República Democrática del Congo, el refuerzo de la cooperación de la UE en materia de seguridad y el aumento de la participación política femenina en Costa de Marfil.

articles.title: UN: Momentum Builds for Crimes Against Humanity Treaty
articles.summary:
Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              United Nations Headquarters in New York City, US, July 16, 2024.
                    © 2024 Jakub Porzycki/NurPhoto via AP Photo 
          
    


  
(New York) – Developing an effective International Convention to Prevent and Punish Crimes against Humanity will require ambitious and forward-looking diplomacy, Human Rights Watch and Columbia Law School’s Prevention of Crimes Against Humanity Project said today in a new briefing paper outlining 25 recommendations for delegations at the United Nations to consider as they prepare for the formal treaty negotiations.  



      

  
  
    



  
        
  

          
        Recommendations for the International Convention on Prevention and Punishment of Crimes Against Humanity
      
      


  
Crimes against humanity, which include extermination, enslavement, rape, forced pregnancy, persecution, enforced disappearance, and apartheid, among others, when committed as a part of a widespread or systematic attack directed against a civilian population, are among the gravest offenses under international law. Their prohibition is already considered a preemptory norm, something no state can opt out of. A new treaty would bring important coherence and consistency to how these crimes are treated in each jurisdiction and enable cooperation among states to prevent these crimes.“It’s been 80 years since Nazi leaders were charged with crimes against humanity in Nuremberg, but we are still waiting for a treaty exclusively dedicated to addressing them,” said Akshaya Kumar, crisis advocacy director at Human Rights Watch and author of the brief. “Diplomats meeting in New York to address this gap should commit to a process that intentionally challenges the exclusion and inequities that too often defined international lawmaking in the past, so that this treaty better anticipates the next 80 years.”In December 2024, UN member states agreed in General Assembly Resolution 79/122 to move ahead with formal work on this treaty. This process, which will begin with a preparatory committee in January 2026, is a landmark opportunity to consolidate global commitments to prevent and punish these grave crimes. Meetings in New York should be supplemented by regional meetings and consultations to boost participation and accessibility, especially considering growing visa restrictions in the United States.Organizers should also commit to webcast proceedings with simultaneous translation to allow the broadest possible participation in the process. This would include victims’ and survivors’ groups, women’s rights defenders, Indigenous communities, academics, people with disabilities who may require reasonable accommodations to participate, and children and young people. The months ahead will test countries’ resolve to maintain unity and vision against political headwinds, the groups said. To achieve the strongest possible outcome, delegates must be willing to vote when consensus-based decision making, which requires unanimous agreement, creates inevitable roadblocks and delays. UN member states in the General Assembly Sixth Committee, the UN’s legal forum, met earlier in October 2025 to discuss the road toward formal negotiations. Country after country reaffirmed support for the process outlined in the December 2024 resolution and expressed their intention to participate in negotiations to develop a convention that would better protect civilians from these atrocity crimes. Led by Costa Rica, dozens of delegations from Africa, Latin America, Europe, and Asia on October 13 vocally called for the inclusion of civil society organizations in every stage. They even urged the inclusion of organizations that do not have formal “consultative” status at the UN’s Economic and Social Council, recognizing that this accreditation is difficult to obtain and can be challenging to maintain for grassroots groups. In comments at the same meeting, Germany specifically noted the importance of allowing civil society organizations to participate in the “working group” sessions planned for January 2026.The January meetings will also include a working group in which each delegation will have a chance to share its views on possible amendments to the text of a set of draft articles, which were prepared by the International Law Commission and originally published in 2019. These draft articles have already been the subject of discussions at two “resumed” sessions of the Sixth Committee in 2023 and 2024, and in a round of written comments, and are addressed in the briefing paper released today. By April 30, 2026, states will have to submit proposals for amendments to the 2019 draft articles. These proposals, together with the draft articles, will be included in a compilation for states to consider at the planned 2028 and 2029 meetings of the plenipotentiary conference negotiations. The treaty could anchor justice for crimes against humanity more solidly in international law, spurring states to adopt national laws and bolstering the efforts of domestic courts through mutual legal assistance. Ideally, negotiators will use the multi-year process to refine the terms of the treaty so that it better recognizes the unique harms faced by women, people with disabilities, children, and other groups. The final text should also include procedural protections for the accused, limit safe havens for suspects, and recognize victims’ rights, particularly to reparations, while maintaining maximum scope for jurisdiction.“It’s more important than ever for governments to reaffirm their commitment to the rule of law and resist any effort to dilute the convention’s core principles, including on prevention,” said Christine Ryan, director of Columbia Law School’s Prevention of Crimes Against Humanity Project.The groups, in the briefing paper, spotlighted key elements of the draft articles that are especially important to maintain. They are also advancing 13 possible amendments to the draft articles that they hope the countries will adopt as their own and submit as proposals before the April 30, 2026, deadline. The growing momentum around the formal process toward a treaty stands out at a time when, more than ever, and over the opposition of big powers, the world needs to bolster multilateralism. The leadership of The Gambia, Mexico, Costa Rica, and Sierra Leone has been essential. “The collective will of supportive states, especially with leadership from the Global South and the determination of civil society, will be necessary to ensure an effective treaty becomes reality,” said Richard Dicker, senior legal adviser at Human Rights Watch, who has been working for years to move the treaty process forward. “From El Fasher to Gaza City, Cox’s Bazaar to Mariupol, victims and survivors should be the moral compass of this process. Their courage reminds us why accountability matters.”
articles.content:
Click to expand Image United Nations Headquarters in New York City, US, July 16, 2024. © 2024 Jakub Porzycki/NurPhoto via AP Photo

(New York) – Developing an effective International Convention to Prevent and Punish Crimes against Humanity will require ambitious and forward-looking diplomacy, Human Rights Watch and Columbia Law School’s Prevention of Crimes Against Humanity Project said today in a new briefing paper outlining 25 recommendations for delegations at the United Nations to consider as they prepare for the formal treaty negotiations.

Crimes against humanity, which include extermination, enslavement, rape, forced pregnancy, persecution, enforced disappearance, and apartheid, among others, when committed as a part of a widespread or systematic attack directed against a civilian population, are among the gravest offenses under international law. Their prohibition is already considered a preemptory norm, something no state can opt out of. A new treaty would bring important coherence and consistency to how these crimes are treated in each jurisdiction and enable cooperation among states to prevent these crimes.

“It’s been 80 years since Nazi leaders were charged with crimes against humanity in Nuremberg, but we are still waiting for a treaty exclusively dedicated to addressing them,” said Akshaya Kumar, crisis advocacy director at Human Rights Watch and author of the brief. “Diplomats meeting in New York to address this gap should commit to a process that intentionally challenges the exclusion and inequities that too often defined international lawmaking in the past, so that this treaty better anticipates the next 80 years.”

In December 2024, UN member states agreed in General Assembly Resolution 79/122 to move ahead with formal work on this treaty. This process, which will begin with a preparatory committee in January 2026, is a landmark opportunity to consolidate global commitments to prevent and punish these grave crimes. Meetings in New York should be supplemented by regional meetings and consultations to boost participation and accessibility, especially considering growing visa restrictions in the United States.

Organizers should also commit to webcast proceedings with simultaneous translation to allow the broadest possible participation in the process. This would include victims’ and survivors’ groups, women’s rights defenders, Indigenous communities, academics, people with disabilities who may require reasonable accommodations to participate, and children and young people.

The months ahead will test countries’ resolve to maintain unity and vision against political headwinds, the groups said. To achieve the strongest possible outcome, delegates must be willing to vote when consensus-based decision making, which requires unanimous agreement, creates inevitable roadblocks and delays.

UN member states in the General Assembly Sixth Committee, the UN’s legal forum, met earlier in October 2025 to discuss the road toward formal negotiations. Country after country reaffirmed support for the process outlined in the December 2024 resolution and expressed their intention to participate in negotiations to develop a convention that would better protect civilians from these atrocity crimes. Led by Costa Rica, dozens of delegations from Africa, Latin America, Europe, and Asia on October 13 vocally called for the inclusion of civil society organizations in every stage. They even urged the inclusion of organizations that do not have formal “consultative” status at the UN’s Economic and Social Council, recognizing that this accreditation is difficult to obtain and can be challenging to maintain for grassroots groups. In comments at the same meeting, Germany specifically noted the importance of allowing civil society organizations to participate in the “working group” sessions planned for January 2026.

The January meetings will also include a working group in which each delegation will have a chance to share its views on possible amendments to the text of a set of draft articles, which were prepared by the International Law Commission and originally published in 2019. These draft articles have already been the subject of discussions at two “resumed” sessions of the Sixth Committee in 2023 and 2024, and in a round of written comments, and are addressed in the briefing paper released today. By April 30, 2026, states will have to submit proposals for amendments to the 2019 draft articles. These proposals, together with the draft articles, will be included in a compilation for states to consider at the planned 2028 and 2029 meetings of the plenipotentiary conference negotiations.

The treaty could anchor justice for crimes against humanity more solidly in international law, spurring states to adopt national laws and bolstering the efforts of domestic courts through mutual legal assistance. Ideally, negotiators will use the multi-year process to refine the terms of the treaty so that it better recognizes the unique harms faced by women, people with disabilities, children, and other groups. The final text should also include procedural protections for the accused, limit safe havens for suspects, and recognize victims’ rights, particularly to reparations, while maintaining maximum scope for jurisdiction.

“It’s more important than ever for governments to reaffirm their commitment to the rule of law and resist any effort to dilute the convention’s core principles, including on prevention,” said Christine Ryan, director of Columbia Law School’s Prevention of Crimes Against Humanity Project.

The groups, in the briefing paper, spotlighted key elements of the draft articles that are especially important to maintain. They are also advancing 13 possible amendments to the draft articles that they hope the countries will adopt as their own and submit as proposals before the April 30, 2026, deadline.

The growing momentum around the formal process toward a treaty stands out at a time when, more than ever, and over the opposition of big powers, the world needs to bolster multilateralism. The leadership of The Gambia, Mexico, Costa Rica, and Sierra Leone has been essential.

“The collective will of supportive states, especially with leadership from the Global South and the determination of civil society, will be necessary to ensure an effective treaty becomes reality,” said Richard Dicker, senior legal adviser at Human Rights Watch, who has been working for years to move the treaty process forward. “From El Fasher to Gaza City, Cox’s Bazaar to Mariupol, victims and survivors should be the moral compass of this process. Their courage reminds us why accountability matters.”
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the significant international diplomatic progress toward creating a dedicated treaty to prevent and punish crimes against humanity, a major step for global justice and human rights protection. The treaty aims to unify legal frameworks across countries, enhance cooperation, and include marginalized groups, reflecting broad global commitment and a meaningful positive impact on civilian protection worldwide.
articles.personality_title: UN begins formal steps toward treaty to prevent crimes against humanity
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Crimes against humanity include serious acts like murder, enslavement, and persecution when done on a large scale against civilians. Although these crimes are already illegal worldwide, there is no single treaty focused just on preventing and punishing them.

**What happened** – In December 2024, United Nations member countries agreed to start formal work on a treaty dedicated to these crimes. Preparations will begin in January 2026 with meetings to discuss draft articles created in 2019. Many countries and civil society groups, including victims’ representatives, will be involved in shaping the treaty.

**Impact** – This treaty aims to make the fight against crimes against humanity clearer and stronger by uniting laws across countries and improving cooperation. It will also recognize the special needs of women, children, disabled people, and victims, while protecting the rights of the accused. This is a big step toward justice and better protection for civilians worldwide.

**What's next step** – Countries will submit proposals to improve the treaty by April 2026. Negotiations will continue in 2028 and 2029 to finalize the agreement. The process will include wide participation and use webcasts to reach groups who cannot attend in person.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The UN is moving forward with a new treaty to better prevent and punish crimes against humanity, aiming for stronger global justice and protection for victims.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’ONU lance les négociations pour un traité contre les crimes contre l’humanité
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les crimes contre l’humanité regroupent des actes graves comme le meurtre, l’esclavage et la persécution lorsqu’ils sont commis à grande échelle contre des civils. Bien que ces crimes soient déjà interdits dans le monde, il n’existe pas de traité unique dédié à leur prévention et sanction.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En décembre 2024, les États membres de l’ONU ont accepté de commencer officiellement les travaux sur un traité consacré à ces crimes. Les préparatifs débuteront en janvier 2026 avec des réunions pour discuter d’un projet d’articles rédigé en 2019. De nombreux pays et groupes de la société civile, y compris des représentants des victimes, participeront à l’élaboration du traité.

**Impact** – Ce traité vise à renforcer la lutte contre les crimes contre l’humanité en unifiant les lois des pays et en améliorant la coopération. Il prendra aussi en compte les besoins spécifiques des femmes, des enfants, des personnes handicapées et des victimes, tout en protégeant les droits des accusés. C’est une avancée majeure pour la justice et la protection des civils dans le monde.

**Prochaine étape** – Les pays devront soumettre des propositions d’amélioration du traité avant avril 2026. Les négociations se poursuivront en 2028 et 2029 pour finaliser l’accord. Le processus inclura une large participation et des webdiffusions pour permettre aux groupes éloignés de suivre les débats.

**Résumé en une phrase** – L’ONU avance vers un nouveau traité pour mieux prévenir et punir les crimes contre l’humanité, renforçant la justice mondiale et la protection des victimes.
articles.personality_title_es: La ONU inicia pasos formales para un tratado contra los crímenes de lesa humanidad
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los crímenes de lesa humanidad incluyen actos graves como el asesinato, la esclavitud y la persecución cuando se cometen a gran escala contra civiles. Aunque estos crímenes ya son ilegales en todo el mundo, no existe un tratado dedicado exclusivamente a prevenirlos y castigarlos.

**Qué pasó** – En diciembre de 2024, los países miembros de la ONU acordaron comenzar el trabajo formal en un tratado dedicado a estos crímenes. Los preparativos empezarán en enero de 2026 con reuniones para discutir un borrador de artículos creado en 2019. Muchos países y grupos de la sociedad civil, incluidos representantes de víctimas, participarán en la creación del tratado.

**Impacto** – Este tratado busca fortalecer la lucha contra los crímenes de lesa humanidad unificando las leyes entre países y mejorando la cooperación. También reconocerá las necesidades especiales de mujeres, niños, personas con discapacidad y víctimas, mientras protege los derechos de los acusados. Es un paso importante hacia la justicia y mejor protección para los civiles en todo el mundo.

**Próximo paso** – Los países deberán presentar propuestas para mejorar el tratado antes de abril de 2026. Las negociaciones continuarán en 2028 y 2029 para finalizar el acuerdo. El proceso incluirá amplia participación y transmisiones en línea para llegar a grupos que no puedan asistir en persona.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La ONU avanza hacia un nuevo tratado para prevenir y castigar mejor los crímenes de lesa humanidad, buscando justicia global y protección para las víctimas.

articles.title: Press release - MEPs to visit Democratic Republic of the Congo
articles.summary: A group of eight MEPs from the European Parliament’s Committee on Development and Subcommittee on Human Rights begin a three-day mission to the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) today.Committee on Development Source : © European Union, 2025 - EP
articles.content:
The eight-member delegation of MEPs are in the DRC, from Monday 27 to Wednesday 29 October, to assess the EU's approach to sustainable development in fragile settings, and what lessons can be learned on the practical implementation of the development, humanitarian and peace nexus.

They will meet relevant stakeholders and visit projects in Lubumbashi to consider how the EU’s flagship Global Gateway initiative works in practice in the DRC. MEPs will also evaluate efforts to support governance and transparency in the management of the DRC’s natural resources, in particular given the critical role of Congolese minerals in global critical raw materials supply chains and taking into account the wider human rights and social cohesion aspects.

In the course of their three-day mission, MEPs will meet local government officials, representatives of civil society organisations active in sustainable development, biodiversity conservation, mining governance, and the protection of human rights in the extractive industries. They will also make a number of field trips to see first-hand the impact of EU support for projects involved in agriculture, , technical and vocational training, local community participation, women's empowerment, and the prevention of child labour practices.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a European Parliament delegation visiting the DRC to assess and support sustainable development, governance, human rights, and social cohesion, with a focus on practical implementation and local impact. This mission has broad significance for development, human rights, and resource governance in a fragile setting, involving tangible projects and community empowerment efforts.
articles.personality_title: European Parliament delegation visits Congo to support sustainable development and human rights
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) faces challenges in managing its natural resources and supporting sustainable growth while protecting human rights. The European Union (EU) has initiatives aimed at helping countries like the DRC develop in a fair and lasting way.

**What happened** – From October 27 to 29, eight members of the European Parliament (MEPs) visited the DRC. They are part of the EU’s Committee on Development and Subcommittee on Human Rights. During their three-day visit, they met local leaders, civil society groups, and project teams in Lubumbashi. They checked how EU programs, like the Global Gateway initiative, are working on the ground. They also looked at efforts to improve how the DRC manages its important minerals, while supporting human rights and community well-being.

**Impact** – This visit is important because it shows the EU’s commitment to helping the DRC in practical ways. The MEPs saw projects that help farmers, train young people, empower women, and fight child labor. They also talked with groups that protect the environment and promote fair use of mining resources. This hands-on approach helps ensure that aid reaches communities and respects human rights.

**What's next step** – The MEPs will use what they learned to advise the European Parliament on how to improve support for the DRC. This could lead to better policies and more effective projects that balance economic growth with social fairness and environmental care.

**One-sentence takeaway** – European Parliament members visited the DRC to review and strengthen EU efforts promoting sustainable development, good governance, and human rights in the country.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une délégation du Parlement européen visite le Congo pour soutenir le développement durable et les droits humains
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La République démocratique du Congo (RDC) rencontre des défis pour gérer ses ressources naturelles et soutenir une croissance durable tout en protégeant les droits humains. L’Union européenne (UE) a des initiatives pour aider les pays comme la RDC à se développer de manière juste et durable.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Du 27 au 29 octobre, huit membres du Parlement européen (députés européens) ont visité la RDC. Ils font partie du Comité du développement et de la Sous-commission des droits de l’homme de l’UE. Pendant ces trois jours, ils ont rencontré des responsables locaux, des groupes de la société civile et des équipes de projets à Lubumbashi. Ils ont évalué le fonctionnement des programmes européens, comme l’initiative Global Gateway. Ils ont aussi examiné les efforts pour mieux gérer les minéraux importants de la RDC tout en soutenant les droits humains et le bien-être des communautés.

**Impact** – Cette visite est importante car elle montre l’engagement de l’UE à aider la RDC de manière concrète. Les députés ont vu des projets qui aident les agriculteurs, forment les jeunes, donnent plus de pouvoir aux femmes et combattent le travail des enfants. Ils ont aussi échangé avec des groupes qui protègent l’environnement et encouragent une exploitation minière équitable. Cette approche pratique aide à s’assurer que l’aide arrive aux communautés et respecte les droits humains.

**Prochaine étape** – Les députés utiliseront ce qu’ils ont appris pour conseiller le Parlement européen sur comment mieux soutenir la RDC. Cela pourrait conduire à de meilleures politiques et à des projets plus efficaces qui équilibrent croissance économique, justice sociale et protection de l’environnement.

**Phrase clé** – Des députés européens ont visité la RDC pour évaluer et renforcer les efforts de l’UE en faveur du développement durable, de la bonne gouvernance et des droits humains dans le pays.
articles.personality_title_es: Delegación del Parlamento Europeo visita el Congo para apoyar el desarrollo sostenible y los derechos humanos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La República Democrática del Congo (RDC) enfrenta desafíos para manejar sus recursos naturales y apoyar un crecimiento sostenible mientras protege los derechos humanos. La Unión Europea (UE) tiene iniciativas para ayudar a países como la RDC a desarrollarse de manera justa y duradera.

**Qué pasó** – Del 27 al 29 de octubre, ocho miembros del Parlamento Europeo (MEP) visitaron la RDC. Forman parte del Comité de Desarrollo y del Subcomité de Derechos Humanos de la UE. Durante su visita de tres días, se reunieron con líderes locales, grupos de la sociedad civil y equipos de proyectos en Lubumbashi. Revisaron cómo funcionan en la práctica los programas de la UE, como la iniciativa Global Gateway. También evaluaron los esfuerzos para mejorar la gestión de los minerales clave de la RDC, apoyando los derechos humanos y el bienestar comunitario.

**Impacto** – Esta visita es importante porque muestra el compromiso de la UE para ayudar a la RDC de manera práctica. Los MEP vieron proyectos que apoyan a agricultores, capacitan a jóvenes, empoderan a mujeres y combaten el trabajo infantil. También hablaron con grupos que protegen el medio ambiente y promueven un uso justo de los recursos mineros. Este enfoque práctico ayuda a que la ayuda llegue a las comunidades y respete los derechos humanos.

**Próximo paso** – Los MEP usarán lo aprendido para aconsejar al Parlamento Europeo sobre cómo mejorar el apoyo a la RDC. Esto puede llevar a mejores políticas y proyectos más efectivos que equilibren el crecimiento económico con la justicia social y el cuidado ambiental.

**Frase clave** – Miembros del Parlamento Europeo visitaron la RDC para revisar y fortalecer los esfuerzos de la UE en desarrollo sostenible, buena gobernanza y derechos humanos en el país.

articles.title: Bulgaria, as a member of Schengen, will continue to contribute to the overall security of the European Union, said the Bulgarian interior minister
articles.summary: For the second consecutive year, a 70% decrease in migrant pressure towards Bulgaria is reported.
articles.content:
SOFIA – Bulgaria, as a member of Schengen, will continue to contribute to the overall security of the European Union. This was stated by Bulgaria’s Minister of Interior Daniel Mitov during the international conference “Bulgaria in Schengen,” part of a series of initiatives by the European Union (EU) to mark the 40th anniversary of the signing of the Schengen Agreement.

According to him, ensuring the internal security of the country and at the borders remains a top priority for the government. “After the removal of control at internal borders, we are implementing a full range of compensatory measures, thanks to which we do not report changes in crime levels,” said the minister. He added that in November, Bulgaria is set to undergo its first periodic assessment under Schengen, now as a full member. We expect positive results that will demonstrate the excellent preparedness of the staff for the implementation of Schengen legislation, Mitov stated.

Bulgaria has invested significant resources to enhance the security of its borders by modernizing equipment, technical infrastructure, and information-communication systems, said Mitov. According to him, Schengen contributes to economic development, the transport sector, and tourism, facilitating the transfer of goods and promoting Bulgaria as a tourist destination. Schengen is the brightest symbol of European unity, trust, and solidarity, said the Minister of Interior.

For the second consecutive year, a 70% decrease in migrant pressure towards Bulgaria has been reported, announced Chief Commissioner Anton Zlatanov, Director of the General Directorate “Border Police” (GDGP). He stated that Bulgaria is a secure external border of the European Union and is becoming increasingly secure.

Bulgaria’s membership in Schengen is recognition of its ability to effectively protect one of the most sensitive and heavily trafficked borders of the European Union, said Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs Elena Shekerletova. “Just from the delay in removing land border control, Bulgaria has lost over 1.6 billion leva annually,” she added. Europe is facing a number of challenges, but through solidarity, trust, and joint efforts, we can preserve Schengen as one of the most valuable achievements of European integration, Shekerletova further pointed out.

Bulgaria became a full member of the Schengen area on January 1, 2025, after a process lasting 18 years. The decision to remove checks at Bulgaria’s and Romania’s land Schengen borders at the beginning of this year was made by the EU Council on December 12, 2024, at the end of the Hungarian presidency. It affects checks at the borders of Bulgaria with Greece and Romania, and of Romania with Bulgaria and Hungary. As of March 31, 2024, checks at the air and sea Bulgarian and Romanian Schengen borders were removed by a decision made at the end of the Spanish presidency in 2023. (October 24, 2025)
articles.reasoning: Bulgaria's full membership in the Schengen area represents a significant milestone in European integration, enhancing security, facilitating free movement, and promoting economic development. The reported 70% decrease in migrant pressure and the country's investment in border security demonstrate tangible benefits for the EU and its citizens. The story focuses on a clear, impactful event with broad significance for the general public across Europe.
articles.personality_title: Bulgaria strengthens EU security with full Schengen membership and 70% drop in migrant pressure
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Bulgaria recently became a full member of the Schengen area, a group of European countries that allow free movement across their borders without routine checks. This membership means Bulgaria shares responsibility for keeping the EU’s external borders safe.

**What happened** – On January 1, 2025, Bulgaria officially joined the Schengen zone after 18 years of preparation. Since then, border checks with neighboring countries like Greece and Romania have been removed. At the same time, Bulgaria has invested in new technology and staff training to keep its borders secure. The country also reported a 70% decrease in migrant pressure for the second year in a row.

**Impact** – Bulgaria’s Schengen membership shows it can protect one of the EU’s busiest borders while allowing people and goods to move more easily. This helps businesses and tourism grow by making travel simpler. The big drop in migrant pressure means fewer challenges at the borders, making the area safer for everyone. Bulgaria’s efforts prove that security and open borders can work together.

**What's next step** – In November 2025, Bulgaria will have its first official review as a Schengen member to confirm it meets all rules and standards. Positive results will strengthen trust in Bulgaria’s border management. Meanwhile, the country will continue improving its systems to support the EU’s shared security.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Bulgaria’s full Schengen membership and strong border management have led to safer borders and smoother travel within the European Union.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Bulgarie renforce la sécurité de l’UE avec son adhésion complète à Schengen et une baisse de 70 % de la pression migratoire
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La Bulgarie est récemment devenue membre à part entière de l’espace Schengen, un groupe de pays européens qui permettent la libre circulation sans contrôles habituels aux frontières. Cette adhésion signifie que la Bulgarie partage la responsabilité de la sécurité des frontières extérieures de l’UE.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 1er janvier 2025, la Bulgarie a officiellement rejoint la zone Schengen après 18 ans de préparation. Depuis, les contrôles aux frontières avec des pays voisins comme la Grèce et la Roumanie ont été supprimés. En même temps, la Bulgarie a investi dans de nouvelles technologies et la formation du personnel pour assurer la sécurité des frontières. Le pays a également signalé une baisse de 70 % de la pression migratoire pour la deuxième année consécutive.

**Impact** – L’adhésion de la Bulgarie à Schengen montre qu’elle peut protéger l’une des frontières les plus fréquentées de l’UE tout en facilitant la circulation des personnes et des marchandises. Cela aide les entreprises et le tourisme à se développer grâce à des voyages simplifiés. La forte baisse de la pression migratoire signifie moins de difficultés aux frontières, ce qui rend la région plus sûre pour tous. Les efforts de la Bulgarie prouvent qu’on peut concilier sécurité et frontières ouvertes.

**Prochaine étape** – En novembre 2025, la Bulgarie aura sa première évaluation officielle en tant que membre Schengen pour confirmer qu’elle respecte toutes les règles et normes. Des résultats positifs renforceront la confiance dans la gestion des frontières bulgare. En attendant, le pays continuera d’améliorer ses systèmes pour soutenir la sécurité partagée de l’UE.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – L’adhésion complète de la Bulgarie à Schengen et une gestion efficace des frontières ont conduit à des frontières plus sûres et à une circulation plus fluide au sein de l’Union européenne.
articles.personality_title_es: Bulgaria fortalece la seguridad de la UE con su plena adhesión a Schengen y una caída del 70 % en la presión migratoria
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Bulgaria se convirtió recientemente en miembro pleno del área Schengen, un grupo de países europeos que permiten la libre circulación sin controles habituales en las fronteras. Esta membresía significa que Bulgaria comparte la responsabilidad de proteger las fronteras exteriores de la UE.

**Qué pasó** – El 1 de enero de 2025, Bulgaria se unió oficialmente a la zona Schengen tras 18 años de preparación. Desde entonces, se eliminaron los controles fronterizos con países vecinos como Grecia y Rumania. Al mismo tiempo, Bulgaria invirtió en nueva tecnología y capacitación del personal para mantener sus fronteras seguras. El país reportó una disminución del 70 % en la presión migratoria por segundo año consecutivo.

**Impacto** – La membresía de Bulgaria en Schengen demuestra que puede proteger una de las fronteras más transitadas de la UE mientras facilita el movimiento de personas y mercancías. Esto ayuda a que crezcan los negocios y el turismo al simplificar los viajes. La gran caída en la presión migratoria significa menos desafíos en las fronteras, haciendo la zona más segura para todos. Los esfuerzos de Bulgaria prueban que la seguridad y las fronteras abiertas pueden funcionar juntas.

**Próximo paso** – En noviembre de 2025, Bulgaria tendrá su primera revisión oficial como miembro de Schengen para confirmar que cumple con todas las reglas y estándares. Resultados positivos fortalecerán la confianza en la gestión fronteriza de Bulgaria. Mientras tanto, el país seguirá mejorando sus sistemas para apoyar la seguridad compartida de la UE.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La adhesión plena de Bulgaria a Schengen y su fuerte gestión fronteriza han llevado a fronteras más seguras y viajes más fluidos dentro de la Unión Europea.

articles.title: Two women candidates try their luck in the Ivory Coast’s 2025 presidential elections
articles.summary: Côte d'Ivoire held its presidential elections on October 25, 2025. Two women, including a former First Lady, were among the five candidates seeking the highest political office. The results are still being tallied.
articles.content:
The Ivory Coast held its presidential elections on October 25, 2025. Two women, including a former First Lady, were among the five candidates running for the highest political office for the next five years.

The Ivorian electoral process, in which the president is elected through universal suffrage, is fraught with tension. This is due to the disqualification of some key opposition candidates and the approval of others, such as Alassane Ouattara, who has been president since 2011 and is seeking reelection in a fourth consecutive term.

Incumbent president and candidate for the Rally of Houphouëtists for Democracy and Peace (RHDP), Alassane Ouattara, faced four opposition candidates: Simone Éhivet Gbagbo, former First Lady and candidate for the Movement of Capable Generations (MGC); Ahoua Don Mello, professor and independent candidate; Henriette Lagou Adjoua, candidate for the Group of Political Partners for Peace (GP-PAIX), and Jean-Louis Billon, 60, candidate for the Democratic Congress.

These five candidates, who the Constitutional Council has approved, campaigned throughout the country, which has over 32 million citizens and is listed as a hybrid democratic regime in The Economist Intelligence Unit’s 2024 report.

The two women candidates were close to Laurent Gbagbo, president from 2000–2011. Simone was the former president’s wife, and Henriette Lagou Adjoua worked with Gbagbo as a minister.

Who is Simone Éhivet Gbagbo?

Born in Moossou, a small village in the Grand-Bassam commune, 43 kilometers east of Abidjan, in the Ivory Coast in 1949, Simone Ehivet Gbagbo is a professional historian. She was also a teacher, enabling her to participate in the 1982 teachers’ strikes before embarking on a political career with the creation of the Ivorian Popular Front (FPI), a political party she founded with her ex-husband and other politicians. Simone held a political position as a member of parliament for her party from 1996 until 2004.

Her influence on the Ivorian political scene was particularly notable for her position as First Lady between 2000 and 2010. In 2011, during the crisis after Alassane Ouattara’s election, which the Gbagbo family contested, Simone and her ex-husband were arrested. While her ex-husband appeared before the International Criminal Court (ICC) in 2012, an Ivorian court sentenced her to 20 years’ imprisonment in 2015, before acquitting her in 2018.

For the October 2025 elections, she sought to build on her experience, offering the Ivory Coast a program geared towards justice, healthcare reform, security, and the economy.

She also has considerable support on the Ivorian political scene, especially from Charles Blé Goudé, president of the Pan-African Congress for Justice and Equality of Peoples (COJEP), whose candidacy was rejected.

Who is Henriette Lagou Adjoua

Born in Daoukro, a town in east-central Ivory Coast, on June 22, 1959, Henriette Adjoua Lagou graduated in social security after extensive studies in her home country and France. In October 2000, she started out in politics as the Minister of Family, Women, and Children in Pascal Affi N’Guessan’s government.

As a writer, she raised the debate on the barriers preventing Ivorian female politicians from rising to the nation’s highest office in her 2025 book “Why Not a Woman?”

She is also known for fighting for women’s rights in the Ivory Coast. As a former unsuccessful candidate in the 2015 presidential elections, she will run for a second time. Henriette put peace, national reconciliation, stability, dialogue, and social cohesion at the center of her election campaign for sustainable development.

High tensions ahead of the vote

The election campaigns began throughout the country on October 10, 2025, against this backdrop of tension. All candidates that the Constitutional Council approved did their utmost to appeal to and convince the Ivorian people with their social projects.

Meanwhile, excluded candidates call on their supporters to protest against these elections going ahead. Instead, they demand inclusive dialogue, as explained in this Africa News video report:

Despite the ban on protests, citizens poured onto the streets of Abidjan and other towns across the country to denounce the current regime’s power grab. These protests often resulted in arrests. According to an article by media group Jeune Afrique, the authorities announced the arrest of around 700 protesters. Fifty were sentenced to three years’ imprisonment for acts of “public disorder, unlawful assembly, and participation in a banned march.”

On October 17, 2025, Sansan Kambilé, Ivorian Minister of Justice, suggested a possible restriction on the freedom to protest. He said:

(…) l’exercice du droit de manifester peut « faire l’objet de restrictions […] dans l’intérêt de la sécurité nationale, de la sûreté publique, de l’ordre public ». (…) les manifestations qui ont eu lieu depuis samedi « revêtent un caractère subversif » et sont « marquées par une violence incompatible avec les exigences de la loi ».

Exercising the right to protest ‘may be subject to restrictions in the interest of national security, public safety, and public order.’ The protests that have taken place since Saturday are of a subversive nature and are marked by violence incompatible with the requirements of the law.

In total, more than 8.7 million voters went to the polls.

Today, women’s involvement in politics allows all women to dream of holding presidential office in the Ivory Coast and across the continent. Two African women have already done it: Samia Suluhu, President of the Republic of Tanzania since March 19, 2021, and Netumbo Nandi-Ndaitwah, President of the Republic of Namibia since March 21, 2025.

The ballots are still being tallied, though early counts indicate incumbent Alassane Ouattara may be the winner.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights the significant participation of two women candidates in the Ivory Coast's 2025 presidential elections, representing progress in women's political representation and empowerment in a country and continent where female leadership at the highest level remains rare. This has broad societal significance and offers hope for gender equality and democratic participation, despite the tense political context.
articles.personality_title: Two women make history as presidential candidates in Ivory Coast's 2025 election
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – On October 25, 2025, the Ivory Coast held presidential elections. The country has a population of over 32 million people and has experienced political tensions in recent years, including protests and disagreements over who can run for president.

**What happened** – Five candidates were approved to run for president, including two women: Simone Éhivet Gbagbo, a former First Lady, and Henriette Lagou Adjoua, a former government minister. They campaigned alongside the current president, Alassane Ouattara, who is seeking a fourth term. Voting took place despite protests and arrests related to political disagreements.

**Impact** – The presence of two women candidates in the race is notable because female leadership in Ivory Coast and many African countries is still uncommon. Simone Gbagbo and Henriette Lagou Adjoua bring experience and focus on issues like justice, healthcare, peace, and women’s rights. Their participation encourages more women to get involved in politics and imagine themselves in top leadership roles.

**What's next step** – Votes are still being counted, but early results suggest the current president may win again. The election results will shape Ivory Coast’s future political direction. The strong showing of women candidates could inspire more inclusive political participation in coming years.

**One-sentence takeaway** – For the first time in Ivory Coast’s history, two women have stood for president, marking an important step toward greater gender equality in the country’s politics.
